Project Number: 42515 
Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2009 
 
 
 
India: Multistate and Multisector Project Management 
Capacity Building 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  H. Kim, Urban Development Division, SARD 
   
Team leader  L. B. Sondjaja, Head, Project Administration Unit, SARD 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Aligned with the Government of India’s development objectives, the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) has put the less developed and weak states in India at the main focus of its 
strategy  and  program,  including  financial  support  to  infrastructure  investment  and  capacity 
development  activities  in  urban  development,  roads  and  highways,  water  resources 
management,  public  resource  management,  and  energy  sectors.  One  investment  program 
under the multitranche financing facility1 in the urban development sector was approved in 2009 
and the first tranche project2 is now under implementation in five states—Tripura, Mizoram, 
Sikkim, Nagaland, and Meghalaya. The second tranche of the investment program may be 
processed in 2011. New projects in the transport sector3 and water resources4 sectors are 
programmed for processing and approval in 2010. 
 
2.  Recognizing that the capacity in project preparation and project implementation in the 
less developed states is low, capacity development technical assistance (TA)5 was included in 
ADB’s 2009 country operations business plan for India,6 with the key objective of supporting the 
implementation of ADB operations in those states. Following a discussion with the government 
in October 2009, consensus was reached in principle, on the purpose, scope, implementation 
arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The design and 
monitoring framework for the TA is in Appendix 1. The concept for this TA was approved by 
ADB Management on 13 October 2009. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The  government’s  Eleventh  Five  Year  Plan,  2007–2012,7 outlines  the  government’s 
development strategy that includes the reduction in interstate disparities. It seeks to redress 
interstate divides in economic and social indicators by proposing various instruments (including 
fiscal  incentives  for  lagging  regions,  industrial  policies,  and  directly  targeted  programs)  to 
achieve this objective. ADB has long experience in assisting the lagging states. Since 2003, 
ADB has initiated operations in Assam, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Jammu and Kashmir, Orissa, and 
Uttarakhand. While ADB has responded to the government’s evolving needs, the challenges of 
designing and implementing operations in the states with weak capacity and little familiarity with 
ADB are enormous. ADB’s experience since 2003 has shown that it takes much longer than 
initially anticipated to design and implement investment projects in those states. Building up 
good communication channels with officials of new state governments and executing agencies, 
and familiarizing them with ADB policies and procedures, takes time. Despite these challenges, 
ADB remains committed to engaging with states with weak capacity. Adequate staff and TA 
resources need to be provided for capacity building during processing and implementation. 
 
4.  The involvement of international development agencies has been very limited in the 
lagging states, and experience in the development and implementation of large schemes has

been minimal in most states and government agencies. Most of the concerned government 
agencies in those states have prepared detailed designs only for a few major projects, and 
supervise construction with their own staff. Implementation of projects in those weak states is 
further complicated by limited availability of local contractors, generally not exposed to large-
scale civil works contracts. 
 
5.  Lessons drawn from the implementation of ADB-funded projects in India have shown 
that start-up delays and slow disbursements in the initial years, largely because of delays in 
recruiting  consultants  and  completing  preparatory  work  before  contract  awards,  could  be 
reduced through provision of up-front TA support prior to loan approval. Moreover, lessons from 
ADB’s experience in implementing projects under severe time constraints in locations of difficult 
accessibility and where responsible agencies’ capacity was either limited or had been reduced 
as a result of a disaster (such as in Gujarat,8 Jammu and Kashmir,9 and Kerala and Tamil 
Nadu10)  has  shown  that  the  provision  of  a  dedicated  project  support  team  expedites  the 
implementation process. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The TA will provide capacity building support to the ongoing project as well as future 
projects in weak states. It will help mainstream effective and efficient project implementation, 
leading to timely delivery of project benefits, which in turn will lead to inclusive economic growth 
in those states. The TA outcomes will be improved efficiency and effectiveness in managing, 
implementing, coordinating, and monitoring the implementation of infrastructure and institutional 
reforms under ADB’s investment program. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The TA will be implemented initially in six states, i.e, Tripura, Mizoram, Sikkim, Nagaland, 
Meghalaya where an investment program is currently under implementation (footnote 1), and 
Assam where the processing of the new project in the agriculture and natural resources sector 
is in an advanced stage (footnote 4). The TA scope will be expanded to other weak states as 
new investment projects are processed and approved, and the TA activities will be adjusted as 
appropriate in coordination with the ADB sector divisions that administer those projects. 
 
8.  Enhancing  projects  processing  and  implementation.  Under  the  TA,  a  projects 
support office (PSO) will be established in Guwahati, Assam. Guwahati is selected because of 
its relatively easy access to the other five states as well as to the rest of India. This arrangement 
follows the successful model of the project support unit established in Jammu and Kashmir 
under ADB-financed TA.11 The PSO will be staffed with project implementation specialists as

well as support staff. The team will provide expert assistance and logistical support to ADB 
processing missions and project review missions. The team will also provide assistance to 
officials of the project executing agencies in advance project preparation activities such as 
feasibility studies, detailed project reports, and detailed engineering design. Emphasis will be 
given to project implementation, by reviewing documents prior to submission to ADB (such as 
bidding documents and bid evaluation reports) as well as providing advice in contract awards, 
contract management, construction supervision, disbursement, and financial audit. The team 
will  also  provide  assistance  to  the  project  executing  agencies  in  setting  up  a  project 
management system supported by appropriate computer software. 
 
9.  Developing implementation capacity of state executing agencies. In addition to the 
activities  mentioned  above,  formal  training  and  workshops  will  be  conducted  in  project 
implementation,  including  procurement,  recruitment  of  consultants,  disbursements,  contract 
management, and dispute resolution. The TA will assist the executing agencies in assessing the 
training needs and in developing suitable training programs. The workshops will be conducted 
by inviting resource persons from ADB’s Central Operations Services Office and Controller’s 
Department, as well as from the national training institutions in India. Formal workshops will also 
be conducted to develop capacity in preparing and monitoring the social and environmental 
safeguards in compliance with the safeguards policies of ADB, India, and state governments. 
These workshops will be conducted by ADB’s safeguards specialists as well as officials from the 
government and the states. 
 
10.  Building public relations. The TA will help the executing agencies and urban local 
bodies conduct effective public relations, consultations, and awareness campaigns with project 
stakeholders,  including  state  officials,  municipal  staff  and  elected  representatives, 
nongovernment  organizations,  and  citizens’  groups  to  improve  public  understanding  and 
acceptance of various reforms proposed. A semimonthly publication will be issued featuring 
articles that describe ADB’s activities, as well as salient information about the projects including 
their expected impact, outcome, and outputs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost at $937,500 equivalent, of which $750,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). The 
government, through the states, will provide $187,500 equivalent in kind for counterpart staff, 
data collection, venues, and facilities for workshops and seminars, and other logistical support. 
Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  Because of the multistate and multisector nature of the TA, the Department of Economic 
Affairs of the Ministry of Finance will be the executing agency. ADB and the Department of 
Economic Affairs will jointly plan the TA inputs and activities, and will regularly review the 
progress and effectiveness of the TA implementation. 
 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 26 months, from January 2010 to February 2012. The 
period from January to April 2010 will cover preparatory activities, including selection and 
engagement of key experts and establishment of the PSO. The effective implementation will 
start from April 2010 after the PSO is established and becomes operational. The TA consulting 
services will include national specialists for six positions with total inputs of 68 person-months. 
The expertise required includes a project management specialist (20 person-months) who will

4     
act as overall PSO team coordinator, a procurement specialist (15 person-months), a financial 
management and accounting specialist (15 person-months), an environmental due diligence 
specialist (7 person-months), a social safeguards and resettlement specialist (7 person-months), 
and a public relations specialist (4 person-months). Support staff, including a junior engineer or 
analyst and an office manager or secretary will be provided and hired under the contract of the 
PSO coordinator. Highly qualified and experienced national experts in these areas are available 
in India. Except for the project management specialist, there may be more than one expert for 
one specialist position at a time depending on the work requirement. The outline terms of 
reference for each of the positions are in Appendix 3.  
 
14.  The consultants will be engaged on an individual basis by ADB, in accordance with its 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Individual 
consultants, rather than a firm, are proposed for this TA because (i) the fielding time for each 
consultant should be kept flexible to ensure the optimum outputs, (ii) some of the consultants 
will provide intermittent short inputs over a long period of time, (iii) the teamwork among the 
consultants  is  not  critical,  and  (iv)  the  number  of  consultants  is  not  too  many  and  still 
manageable if they are recruited individually. Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.12  
 
15.  The PSO coordinator will prepare brief monthly reports and comprehensive quarterly 
reports covering the progress of the projects and activities of the PSO. At the end of the TA, the 
PSO coordinator will prepare a final report summarizing the TA’s achievements. Each individual 
consultant is required to prepare an end-of-assignment report for each time they are fielded. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Multistate and Multisector Project Management Capacity Building, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

1.  Project Management Specialist 
 
2.  The specialist will be responsible for the following tasks: 
(i)    Set up the PSO. 
(ii)   Act as overall PSO team coordinator. As such, he or she will be responsible for 
planning,  coordinating,  and  executing  most  activities  under  the  TA,  in  close 
coordination with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and government agencies; 
and for monitoring the work of other consultants to ensure that the objectives of 
the technical assistance (TA) are achieved in a timely manner. 
(iii)   Assist  project  management  and  implementation  units  in  developing  optimal 
managerial and technical staffing structures (as required by each tranche during 
project  implementation)  to  ensure  adequate  staffing,  internal  organizational 
matters, and an efficient system of approvals. Support the preparation of terms of 
reference as necessary. 
(iv)   Assist project management and implementation units in assessing the training 
needs in the project states and in developing a training program to be organized 
during the TA implementation period. 
(v)   Advise  project  management  and  implementation  units  on  best  practices  in 
construction  and  contract  management  using  appropriate  computer  software 
(such as MS Project).  
(vi)   In  consultation  with  ADB  project  officers,  support  project  management  and 
implementation  units  in  (a)  coordinating  all  activities  at  policy  level;

(ix)   Facilitate in obtaining legal opinions at central and state level, to ensure timely

  2.  Procurement Specialist 
 
3.  The procurement specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Advise  project  management  and  implementation  units  on  establishing 
procurement management systems in conformity with ADB guidelines, including 
tendering procedures, prequalification of civil works, wherever necessary, and 
preparing suitable contractual documents.  
(ii)  Review  all  procurement  and  consultant  recruitment  documents  (draft  bidding 
documents,  draft  request  for  proposal,  draft  contract)  after  submission  by 
executing agencies to ADB and provide ADB project officers with comments 
pertaining to their compliance with ADB guidelines. 
(iii)  Review  the  prequalification  reports,  bid  evaluation  reports,  and  reports  on 
evaluation of technical and financial proposals from consultants submitted by the 
executing agencies to ADB, and provide ADB project officers with comments. 
(iv)  Support  ADB  project  officers  in  anticorruption/integrity  efforts  by  conducting 
performance and procurement audits. 
(v)  Provide on-the-job training on procurement to staff to familiarize them with ADB’s 
procurement  and  recruitment  of  consultants’  procedures,  and  support  in 
organizing and conducting workshops and seminars on procurement.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
  3.  Financial Management and Accounting Specialist 
 
4.  The financial management and accounting specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Assist project management and implementation units in establishing an asset 
management  system  and  a  financial  management  and  accounting  system 
including a budgeting and control system, funds flow monitoring system, and a 
system  for  the  audit  of  project  accounts,  and  in  implementing  financial  and 
accounting reforms in the various sectors and states. 
(ii)  Review the government policies affecting the financial performance of municipal 
corporations and identify critical areas for improvement. 
(iii)  Together  with  the  project  management  and  procurement  specialist,  provide 
support to state executing agencies in (a) conducting annual budgeting activities, 
(b) preparing disbursement requests, and (c) preparing key sections pertaining to 
accounting and disbursement in quarterly and annual reports based on an ADB-
agreed template. 
(iv)  Assist the project management and implementation units in preparing claims 
under  retroactive  financing  and  review  on-site  the  said  claims  and  their 
compliance with loan agreement requirements on behalf of ADB. 
(v)  Provide on-the-job training on accounting and disbursement to staff to familiarize 
them with ADB disbursement procedures, and support in organizing workshops 
and seminars on disbursements. 
 
  4.  Environmental Due Diligence Specialist 
 
5.  The environmental due diligence specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Review and assist and/or advise project management units in preparing initial 
environmental  examinations  and/or  environmental  impact  assessment  reports 
required for compliance with ADB safeguards policies for each project and/or 
investment program tranche. 
(ii)  Assist project management and implementation units in conducting environment 
assessments,  including  public  consultations,  and  incorporating  identified 
mitigation measures into the project documents. 
(iii)  Ensure the incorporation of environmental management plans and environmental 
requirements in all bid documents and/or contracts submitted for ADB financing. 
(iv)  Conduct  reviews  and/or  audits  pertaining  to  environmental  compliance  and 
occupational health and safety in ADB projects at least once a year for each 
project. Prepare and submit reports accordingly.  
(v)  Liaise  between  ADB  project  officers  and  state  governments  to  expedite 
clarifications  pertaining  to  safeguards  compliance  with  government  and  ADB 
policies.  
(vi)  Advise  project  management  and  implementation  units  on  complying  with  all 
safeguards requirements, and in obtaining all permits.

Appendix 3           11 
(vii)  Support in organizing workshops and seminars on environmental safeguards and 
compliance. 
 
  5.  Social Safeguards and Resettlement Specialist 
 
6.  The social safeguards and resettlement specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Review  and  assist  and/or  advice  project  management  units  in  preparing 
resettlement  plans  and  indigenous  peoples  development  plans  required  for 
compliance  with  ADB  safeguards  policies  in  each  project  and/or  investment 
program tranche. 
(ii)  Assist project management and implementation units in conducting resettlement 
and  social  safeguards  assessments,  including  public  consultations,  and 
incorporating identified mitigation measures into the project documents. 
(iii)  Supervise  the  implementation  of  resettlement  plans  and  indigenous  peoples 
development  plans,  and  incorporation  of  measures  to  minimize  temporary 
impacts in all bid documents and/or contracts submitted for ADB financing. 
(iv)  Conduct reviews and/or audits pertaining to resettlement and social safeguards 
compliance in ADB projects at least once a year for each project. Prepare and 
submit reports accordingly.  
(v)  Liaise  between  ADB  project  officers  and  state  governments  to  expedite 
clarifications pertaining to social safeguards compliance with government and 
ADB policies.  
(vi)  Support  in  organizing  workshops  and  seminars  on  social  safeguards  and 
resettlement compliance.  
 
  6.  Public Relations Specialist 
 
7.  The public relations specialist will do the following: 
(i)  Assist project states and urban local bodies in establishing good public relations. 
(ii)  Assist the project states and urban local bodies in organizing and carrying out 
stakeholder  consultation  and  awareness  campaigns  in  the  project  cities  to 
improve public understanding and acceptance of those reforms proposed;1 and in 
seeking  feedback  and  building  consensus  for  introducing  the  recommended 
institutional and financial reforms. 
(iii)  Review  the  assessment  reports  on  the  social  profile  of  the  affected  and 
beneficiary  population,  needs  and  aspirations  of  the  target  population,  and 
willingness and affordability to pay for improved services. 
(iv)  Assist project implementation and management offices by introducing staff to 
participatory consultation methods and techniques, and conduct workshops on 
the subject. 
(v)  Review local media and newspapers and liaise with ADB in providing reports on 
any reported grievance and on ADB’s public image aspects in general. 
(vi)  Prepare focused articles describing ADB activities in the six states and prepare 
brochure semiannually.   
                                                 
1  For example, revisions to the property tax systems and levying of charges for service delivery.
